DOC.HEAD: IBM Announces Agreement With Software Company, New PC Model
DOC.TEXT: International Business Machines Corp. has announced a partnership with a small software company that will allow IBM's OfficeVision software to connect with office software systems of other manufacturers. Under the agreement, Soft-Switch, of Wayne, Pa., has designed software that will allow companies using OfficeVision to exchange computer documents and electronic mail with office systems made by Digital Equipment Corp., Wang Laboratories Inc., Hewlett-Packard Co. and others, IBM said Tuesday. OfficeVision, introduced by IBM in May, allows companies using various IBM computers of different sizes to tie them together in one system. The software overcomes the incompatibility of many IBM products, a shortfall that has been exploited by Digital and other companies that make only compatible machines. The Soft-Switch products will be sold by both IBM and Soft-Switch. They will be available Dec. 29 and will be priced from $40,000 to $250,000, IBM said. Separately Tuesday, IBM introduced the most powerful member of its Personal System-2 computer family, a model based on Intel Corp.'s i486 microprocessor. The model, called the PS-2 Model 70 486, is priced at $12,395 and up. In addition, IBM said it would resume shipping a kit to upgrade its earlier PS-2 Model 70 computers by adding the i486 chip. IBM stopped shipping the kits in October after Intel alerted it to a flaw in the chips. The trouble was corrected with a new version of the microprocessor.
